user_request: A Christmas poem about the magic of the season and family togetherness.
final_poem:
# The Gift We Carry

Under the oak, where we used to slide
into each other's laps and laugh,
the snow has come again—its silent ride,
its softest blanket over everything.

I watch my daughters build a wall
of blocks between us, fortifying
some kingdom yet unnamed. They stand
and knock it down together, both laughing,

still small enough that I can hear
their bones doing what bones do
when no one is afraid—their hum
like the low string of some ancient harp.

Merry Christmas, Dad,
you'd say if you could—
your voice would find us through the tree,
would settle in the chimney like smoke

and stay. But I keep lighting it.
The fire eats the paper fast,
then takes the card itself, then yours,
then anything you left behind,

which was why I put your name on the list
this year. The ornament lit up green—
that little light, that stupid light,
the simplest thing in the room

and also the most true. It keeps
going off by itself sometimes at night,
mid-blink, and when it does the house
is filled with what I can only call

your presence. I don't mind. The girls
don't mind. We let it stay—this warmth
that has no source we can see.

Outside, a cardinal hits the window hard,
loss of direction or just practice—
it flies back, red-blazing through the glass,
stays there, stunned, then rights itself

and is gone. The crack it left
is like a word misspoken in another language:
meaning full, meaning strange, meaning
something between us we'll have to translate.

I carry you inside my chest
the way a nut carries its whole world—
pressed shut, kept quiet, with everywhere
it's going already mapped

through every pore. The girls are five and three.
They don't know what I'm carrying.
But they know the chair is softer now,
they know the table holds more chairs,

and that alone is how traditions start:
not remembering correctly, but keeping room.

Come home for Christmas, Uncle.
The door's been open since October.
There's room by the fire. There's room
to be silly, to argue, to sit

in silence while the tree does its work—
that small green engine churning out
the one bright thing a house can make on its own,
that stupid light keeping faith

with every bird that knocks. We'll feed it.
We'll sing the songs we sang when you were ours,
though now they sound like something else entirely,
like an old key turned in a new lock—

and that is magic, and it happens
every year because we keep doing this,
because the house keeps darkening,
because the snow keeps falling

on the things we left outside.
